items.title: Reading config file using tesserocr
items.body:
### Config file has no impact with Tesserocr:

I am using tesseract 4.1.0 and whitelist(tried with black list too) works for me with pytesseract:

```
custom_config = r'-c tessedit_char_whitelist=abcd'
print(pytesseract.image_to_string(img, config=custom_config))
```

 and tried with config file too:

`print(pytesseract.image_to_string(img, config='letters'))`

My test config file is simple as below:

`tessedit_char_blacklist abcd`

But it is NOT working with tesserocr:

```

with PyTessBaseAPI(psm=PSM.SINGLE_COLUMN, oem=OEM.LSTM_ONLY) as api:
api.SetImage(img)
api.SetVariable("tessedit_char_whitelist", "abcd");
api.Recognize()
print(api.GetUTF8Text())
```


below code also not working(tried with blacklist too):

```
with PyTessBaseAPI(psm=PSM.SINGLE_COLUMN, oem=OEM.LSTM_ONLY) as api:
    api.ReadConfigFile("letters")
    api.SetImage(img)
    api.Recognize()
    print(api.GetUTF8Text())
```

### any other method to set config file with tesseocr? Seems it is not the issue with whiteList. I believe the issue is something about reading the config file using tesserocr. Please help!!!

items.title: Allow to set init-only variables in PyTessBaseAPI
items.body:
Hi!

I have found in [tesseract doc](https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tessdoc/blob/master/ControlParams.md) that `load_freq_dawg` and `load_system_dawg` are init only variables. This means they can not be set through `TessBaseAPI::SetVariable`.

This can only be done  [through config files](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50204628/tesseract-api-with-load-system-dawg-and-load-freq-dawg/50210308). 

Is there are planning for `PyTessBaseAPI` class to support init-only variables via config files or arguments?

As said in [tesseract doc](https://tesseract-ocr.github.io/tessdoc/ImproveQuality.html#dictionaries-word-lists-and-patterns), disabling the dictionaries Tesseract uses should increase recognition and speed if most of your text isn't dictionary words.

Thank your in advance.

items.title: Error during setup ‘class tesseract::ResultIterator’ has no member named ‘GetBestLSTMSymbolChoices’
items.body:
Hello, 

Thanks for the repository. I have used it before and I liked the fact that we can set it up as as API to do batch calls and get confidence values. It is very useful.

I am trying to set it up for a newer version of Tesseract and having some difficulty overriding the default settings of setup.py.

Currently `which tesseract` on my Ubuntu 16.04 points to the desired version of Tesseract (4.1.1). However pkg_config is not being updated. Therefore I even tried manually changing the config dictionary in setup.py by providing the correct library and include directories. But the installation still seems to getting an error. items.title: Undefined library order in setup.py
items.body:
Running `pip install .` can result in an unusable `tesserocr.cpython-37m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so`:

    ImportError: /home/stweil/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tesserocr.cpython-37m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so: undefined symbol: curl_easy_perform

or

    ImportError: /home/stweil/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tesserocr.cpython-37m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so: undefined symbol: archive_entry_pathname

This is caused by an undefined order of the libraries given to the linker. The correct order is defined by pkg-config:

    pkg-config --libs --cflags tesseract
    -I/home/stweil/venv/include -I/usr/include/leptonica -L/home/stweil/venv/lib -ltesseract -larchive -lcurl

Running `pip install -v . 2>&1 | grep g++` several times shows different linker statements:

    # good case: -ltesseract -larchive -lcurl -llept
    x86_64-linux-gnu-g++ -pthread -shared -Wl,-O1 -Wl,-Bsymbolic-functions -Wl,-z,relro -Wl,-z,relro -g -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -Wdate-time -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.7/tesserocr.o -L/home/stweil/venv/lib -ltesseract -larchive -lcurl -llept -o build/lib.linux-x86_64-3.7/tesserocr.cpython-37m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so

    # bad case: -lcurl -llept -larchive -ltesseract
    x86_64-linux-gnu-g++ -pthread -shared -Wl,-O1 -Wl,-Bsymbolic-functions -Wl,-z,relro -Wl,-z,relro -g -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -Wdate-time -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.7/tesserocr.o -L/home/stweil/venv/lib -lcurl -llept -larchive -ltesseract -o build/lib.linux-x86_64-3.7/tesserocr.cpython-37m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so

items.title: Tesserocr gives incorrect orientation results with PSM.OSD_ONLY (and different results to command line version)
items.body:
The following code snippet from the pypi project gives an incorrect result after rotating the `eurotext.tif` image (from `tests` directory of repo). E.g. after rotating the image by 180 degrees:

```
from tesserocr import PyTessBaseAPI, PSM

with PyTessBaseAPI(psm=PSM.OSD_ONLY) as api:
    api.SetImageFile("/usr/src/tesseract/testing/eurotext.tif")

    os = api.DetectOS()
    print("Orientation: {orientation}\nOrientation confidence: {oconfidence}\n"
          "Script: {script}\nScript confidence: {sconfidence}".format(**os))
```

Result:
```
Orientation: 0
Orientation confidence: 0.0
Script: 2
Script confidence: nan
```

Running `tesseract /usr/src/tesseract/testing/eurotext.tif- --psm 0` gives:
```
Orientation in degrees: 180
Rotate: 180
Orientation confidence: 28.28
Script: Latin
Script confidence: 6.05
```

Tesserocr: 2.4.1
OS: macOS 10.14.3

tesseract 4.1.0
 leptonica-1.78.0
  libgif 5.1.4 : libjpeg 9c : libpng 1.6.37 : libtiff 4.0.10 : zlib 1.2.11 : libwebp 1.0.3 : libopenjp2 2.3.1

items.title: Add recipe for conda-forge channel
items.body:
Hello @sirfz!

I wonder if there are any plans on creating a recipe for tesserocr on the community-based conda-forge channel for anaconda (https://conda-forge.org). With the tesseract library being available for Linux, OS X and Windows (see https://anaconda.org/conda-forge/tesseract), this would provide the perfect platform to distibute this fantastic package.

Are there any interests in this? I already made a conda recipe a few months ago that integrates well with the tesseract version 4.0.0 from conda-forge (see https://anaconda.org/chilipp/tesserocr, at that time tesseract was only available for linux and osx) and I would be willing to setup the basis for a tesserocr-feedstock on conda-forge (of course with adding you as maintainer). Once this initial setup is sorted out, the maintenance of the feedstock on conda-forge should be pretty straight-forward. What do you think?

items.title: SetImage should not default to JPEG
items.body: When `SetImage` converts a `PIL.Image` to `Pixa`, it uses Pillow's `save()` with the `.format` of the image – or `JPEG` if none is set. This __breaks images with transparency__ (which Tesseract is perfectly capable of processing). Since Leptonica is fully able to handle `PNG`, please use that as a default instead.

items.title: How to create PDFs?
items.body:
Hi,
I'm trying to create a pdf file from various images with this code:

```
from tesserocr import PyTessBaseAPI

tessapi = PyTessBaseAPI(lang='deu')
try:
    tessapi.SetVariable('tessedit_create_pdf', 'True')
    
    tessapi.ProcessPage("TestOcr","files.tes",None,0)
finally:
    tessapi.End()
```

Where files.tes is a text file with the images path.
running this, I got this error:
```
tessapi.ProcessPage("TestOcr","files.tes",None,0)
  File "tesserocr.pyx", line 2066, in tesserocr.PyTessBaseAPI.ProcessPage
TypeError: an integer is required
```
Btw, is this the correct way to set the `tessedit_create_pdf` variable?

items.title: Missing PyLTRResultIterator method RowAttributes
items.body:
tesserocr has no method `PyLTRResultIterator.RowAttributes()
`For tesseract it is defined here:
https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/blob/master/src/ccmain/ltrresultiterator.cpp#L145

It would be quite useful to determine the fontsize for the row if no other font information is availabe(with lstm).

Another possibility would be adapt the check here: 
https://github.com/sirfz/tesserocr/blob/master/tesserocr.pyx#L834

The pointsize is set, even if there is no other font information (see https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/blob/master/src/ccmain/ltrresultiterator.cpp#L174)

items.title: How to do Threading Properly?
items.body:
Hi @sirfz,

could you share an example how to properly use multithreading? For me sequentially calling the tesseract API from the main thread is consistently the fastest, but I am not sure if I am missing something. Below you can find my "benchmark". I get, for instance:

> [SEQUENTIAL] ocr for 4 images took 1.512s
> [THREADED] ocr for 4 images took 1.574s
> [THREADED2] ocr for 4 images took 1.663s

I was not expecting a linear speed up, but some speedup...

```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

import locale
import time
import threading
import os

locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, "C")

import cv2 as cv
import numpy as np
from PIL import Image as PIL_Image
from tesserocr import PyTessBaseAPI, PSM, image_to_text


class TesseractInstance(object):

    PSM_OSD_ONLY = PSM.OSD_ONLY
    PSM_AUTO_OSD = PSM.AUTO_OSD
    PSM_AUTO_ONLY = PSM.AUTO_ONLY
    PSM_AUTO = PSM.AUTO
    PSM_SINGLE_COLUMN = PSM.SINGLE_COLUMN
    PSM_SINGLE_BLOCK_VERT_TEXT = PSM.SINGLE_BLOCK_VERT_TEXT
    PSM_SINGLE_BLOCK = PSM.SINGLE_BLOCK
    PSM_SINGLE_LINE = PSM.SINGLE_LINE
    PSM_SINGLE_WORD = PSM.SINGLE_WORD
    PSM_CIRCLE_WORD = PSM.CIRCLE_WORD
    PSM_SINGLE_CHAR = PSM.SINGLE_CHAR
    PSM_SPARSE_TEXT = PSM.SPARSE_TEXT
    PSM_SPARSE_TEXT_OSD = PSM.SPARSE_TEXT_OSD
    PSM_RAW_LINE = PSM.RAW_LINE
    PSM_COUNT = PSM.COUNT

    def __init__(self, lang="eng"):
        if "TESSDATA_PREFIX" not in os.environ:
            raise RuntimeError("TESSDATA_PREFIX not set")
        self.api = PyTessBaseAPI(lang=lang)

    def __del__(self):
        self.api.End()

    def image_to_text(self, im: np.ndarray, psm=PSM_AUTO):
        if len(im.shape) != 2:
            raise RuntimeError("Expected grayscale image")
        if im.dtype != np.uint8:
            raise RuntimeError("Image must be of type np.uint8")

        self.api.SetPageSegMode(psm)
        self.api.SetImage(PIL_Image.fromarray(im))
        return self.api.GetUTF8Text()


def random_images(width, height, count):
    return [(255 * np.random.uniform(size=[height, width]) > 100).astype(np.uint8) for _ in range(count)]


def test_sequential(ims):
    instance = TesseractInstance()

    t0 = time.time()
    for im in ims:
        instance.image_to_text(im, TesseractInstance.PSM_SINGLE_BLOCK)
    dt = time.time() - t0

    print(f"[SEQUENTIAL] ocr for {len(ims)} images took {dt:.3f}s")


def test_threaded(ims):
    threads = []

    for im in ims:
        instance = TesseractInstance()
        threads.append(threading.Thread(
            target=instance.image_to_text,
            kwargs={"im": im, "psm": TesseractInstance.PSM_SINGLE_BLOCK})
        )

    t0 = time.time()
    for t in threads:
        t.start()
    for t in threads:
        t.join()
    dt = time.time() - t0

    print(f"[THREADED] ocr for {len(ims)} images took {dt:.3f}s")


def test_threaded2(ims):
    threads = []

    for im in ims:
        threads.append(threading.Thread(
            target=image_to_text,
            kwargs={"image": PIL_Image.fromarray(im), "psm": TesseractInstance.PSM_SINGLE_BLOCK})
        )

    t0 = time.time()
    for t in threads:
        t.start()
    for t in threads:
        t.join()
    dt = time.time() - t0

    print(f"[THREADED2] ocr for {len(ims)} images took {dt:.3f}s")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    np.random.seed(123)
    ims = random_images(400, 200, 4)

    test_sequential(ims)
    test_threaded(ims)
    test_threaded2(ims)

    # cv.imshow("waddup?", ims[0])
    # cv.waitKey()

```

items.title: usage of python3 (generator-based) zip in _pixa_to_list causes segfault at pix.informat
items.body:
OS:
`Mac OS X 10.14`
Python: 
`Python 3.6.6`
Tesserocr:
`tesserocr==2.4.0`
Tesseract:
```
tesseract 4.0.0
 leptonica-1.77.0
  libgif 5.1.4 : libjpeg 9c : libpng 1.6.36 : libtiff 4.0.10 : zlib 1.2.11 : libwebp 1.0.2 : libopenjp2 2.3.0
 Found AVX2
 Found AVX
 Found SSE
```

When running tesserocr unmodified, the following code produces a segfault at `_pix_to_image`'s invocation of `pix.informat`:
```
import locale
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_CTYPE, 'C')
import tesserocr
from PIL import Image
with tesserocr.PyTessBaseAPI() as api:
    im = Image.open('[LOCAL_PATH_TO_PROJECT_DIR]/tesserocr/tests/eurotext.tif')
    api.SetImage(im)
    api.Recognize()
    res = list(api.GetWords())
```

I found that by replacing
```
cdef pixa_to_list(Pixa *pixa):
    """Convert Pixa (Array of pixes and boxes) to list of pix, box tuples."""
    return zip((_pix_to_image(pix) for pix in pixa.pix[:pixa.n]), boxa_to_list(pixa.boxa))
```
with
```
cdef pixa_to_list(Pixa *pixa):
    """Convert Pixa (Array of pixes and boxes) to list of pix, box tuples."""
    tuples = []
    for pixbox_tuple in zip((_pix_to_image(pix) for pix in pixa.pix[:pixa.n]), boxa_to_list(pixa.boxa)):
        tuples.append(pixbox_tuple)
    return tuples
```
the segfault is avoided.

Assuming this has something to do with python3's generator-based implementation of `zip`, but wanted to make sure this is not some other issue with my particular versions of C/C++ libs.

items.title: Couldn't import tesserocr, because locale check error
items.body:
I got a import error.

```
import tesserocr
!strcmp(locale, "C"):Error:Assert failed:in file baseapi.cpp, line 203
Abort trap: 6
```

This error was caused by locale check.

Please see [commit](https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/commit/3292484f67af8bdda23aa5e510918d0115785291#diff-903b81bdfe923135ee1d03800c400ed8) .

Simple workaround here .

```
import locale
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, 'C')
import tesserocr
```

I think that it is necessary to add the code somewhere in the appropriate place.

Environment:

- macOS 10.13.6
- Python 3.6.5
- tesserocr  2.3.0
- tesseract 4.0.0-beta.4-20-ge9b4e

In addition, I avoid install error by #129 workaroud.

items.title: Build with tesseract-4.0.0-beta-3 fails, missing include file osdetect.h, easy fix
items.body:
I've built tesseract-4 from source on my Mac, and done the "make install" thing:
```
$ tesseract -v
tesseract 4.0.0-beta.3-180-gab1f
 leptonica-1.76.0
  libjpeg 9c : libpng 1.6.34 : libtiff 4.0.9 : zlib 1.2.11
 Found AVX2
 Found AVX
 Found SSE
```

For tesserocr, I create a virtualenv with python3.6, and see pip failing, first with a warning, then with an error:
```
(.venv3) $ pip install tesserocr
...
    In file included from tesserocr.cpp:621:
    In file included from /usr/local/Cellar/leptonica/1.76.0/include/leptonica/allheaders.h:35:
    In file included from /usr/local/Cellar/leptonica/1.76.0/include/leptonica/alltypes.h:37:
    /usr/local/Cellar/leptonica/1.76.0/include/leptonica/environ.h:158:10: warning: 'HAVE_FSTATAT' macro redefined [-Wmacro-redefined]
    #define  HAVE_FSTATAT     0
             ^
    /Users/chris/.pyenv/versions/3.6.3/include/python3.6m/pyconfig.h:319:9: note: previous definition is here
    #define HAVE_FSTATAT 1
            ^
    tesserocr.cpp:635:10: fatal error: 'tesseract/osdetect.h' file not found
    #include "tesseract/osdetect.h"
```

I can fix the build by copying the osdetect.h file from my tesseract source to my system includes directory:
```
(.venv3) $ cp ./tesseract/src/ccmain/osdetect.h /usr/local/include/tesseract/
(.venv3) $ pip install tesserocr
Collecting tesserocr
Building wheels for collected packages: tesserocr
  Running setup.py bdist_wheel for tesserocr ... done
  ...
Successfully built tesserocr
Installing collected packages: tesserocr
Successfully installed tesserocr-2.3.0
```

I'm not familiar enough with how Tesseract is evolving to understand if this file was forgotten in the "make install" process or it's something that can be worked around in tessocr.

Thanks.

items.title: How to deal with tesseract LC_ALL=C limitation :(
items.body:
I just discovered that tesseract 4 currently works only with LC_ALL set to C.

https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/wiki/4.0x-Common-Errors-and-Resolutions

If you don't do this you' get a segmentation fault as soon as you import tesserocr.

The problem is this: if I set this variable in this way I can no longer print utf-8 text on the console or I get this:

UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character '\xe0' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)

How do you deal with this problem when using tesserocr? Of course I can write my output to a file and other tricks to avoid this problem, but I'm looking for a clean solution, if any.

I realize this is not a tesserocr bug but it is a problem affecting any tesserocr user so maybe we can see if someone has a good solution for this.

Hi to all,
I am trying to generate a pdf through the api but it generates a pdf damaged pdf. 

```python
dirname = os.path.dirname(__file__)
tessdata = os.path.join(dirname, '../tessdata/') 
with PyTessBaseAPI(
    path=tessdata,
    lang='por',
    psm=PSM.SINGLE_BLOCK,
    oem=OEM.LSTM_ONLY) as api:

    api.SetVariable('tessedit_create_pdf', 'true')
    status= api.ProcessPages('./data/outputbase', './data/e72651e8-fd91-4171-8758-485e2f7c8d92.jpg')
    if not status:
        print('error') 
```

Is there any problem with my code?

items.title: Error in `python': double free or corruption on a single Image when using PyTessBaseAPI
items.body:
I'm running a docker image of Ubuntu 14.04 and when I'm running the following code:

```
from tesserocr import PyTessBaseAPI
from PIL import Image

x = Image.open('image.jpg')

with PyTessBaseAPI() as api:
    api.SetImage(x)
    api.Recognize()
    ri=api.GetIterator()
    print api.GetUTF8Text()
    
```
I'm getting the following error:

`Segmentation fault (core dumped)`

I did `free -m` and this is what I got:

```
             total       used       free     shared    buffers     cached
Mem:         12012      10280       1731          1        420       8738
-/+ buffers/cache:       1121      10890
Swap:        12284         64      12220

```


Is this a memory issue? 
Does anyone know how to resolve this?

But I'm still getting the invalid tessdata path error. I've tried the following to fix it:

1. Assigned the environment variable as TESSDATA_PREFIX ='/usr/local/share/'
2. Added path='/usr/local/share/' in PyTessBaseAPI() 

The location of the tessdata folder is correct but I'm still not able to use this.
Note: I'm using docker with ubuntu 14.04 image and tesserocr version is 2.2.2 and tesseract version is 4.00 beta

How do I resolve this issue?

items.title: RuntimeError: No text returned
items.body:
Hello,
using the following code, I print the coordinates and text of each word:
* tesseract 3.04.01 leptonica-1.71  libjpeg 8d : libpng 1.2.50 : libtiff 4.0.3 : zlib 1.2.8)
* tesserocr 2.2.1

```
from tesserocr import PyTessBaseAPI
from tesserocr import RIL
from tesserocr import iterate_level
from PIL import Image

DEFAULT_LANGUAGE = "spa"
filePath = "/home/repository/f5a77ee10b8415286347db3324b221.png"

if __name__ == '__main__':
    img = Image.open(filePath)
    tesseract = PyTessBaseAPI(lang=DEFAULT_LANGUAGE)
    tesseract.SetImage(img)
    tesseract.Recognize()
    iterator = tesseract.GetIterator()            
    text = tesseract.GetUTF8Text()
    if ((not text is None) and (text.strip() != "")):
        level = RIL.WORD
        
        for r in iterate_level(iterator, level):
            rect = r.BoundingBox(level)
            wordText = r.GetUTF8Text(level)
            print str(rect) + "-->" + wordText
            
    tesseract.End() 
```
I am getting this error:
```
 File "/home/jorge/workspace/prueba-tes/src/test3.py", line 22, in <module>
    wordText = r.GetUTF8Text(level)
  File "tesserocr.pyx", line 801, in tesserocr.PyLTRResultIterator.GetUTF8Text (tesserocr.cpp:6435)
RuntimeError: No text returned
```
It fails just at the beginning. I checked and r.BoundingBox(level) returns None before r.GetUTF8Text(level) fails.

I would like to know if the way I am doing it is correct. If it is, should I call r.GetUTF8Text(level) only when r.BoundingBox(level) is not None?

This is the image:
![9f5a77ee10b8415286347db3324b221f pdf_3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23032523/33147571-45c8c06e-cf96-11e7-8e2c-83fba3d8272e.png)

Best Regards.

Jorge Flórez

items.title: tesserocr links to old tesseract
items.body:
I used tesseract 3.05 with tesserocr in my python project, but updated it on my mac after deleting the old version with brew install tesseract --HEAD to get the new version tesseract 4.0.
I used pip uninstall tesserocr and reinstalled it, but when I try to use it in python it still seems to link to the old tesseract lib.
Even after reinstalling both tesserocr and tesseract again. What am I missing here?

items.title: Cannot build on Debian Jessie and below
items.body:
- No tesseract.pc is installed by any tesseract packages on Debian Jessie and below
- Setup.py should be robust enough against missing `.pc` files and provide alternative ways of installing with PIP
- Alternatively, README should be updated with a warning

items.title: Passing binarized image to Tesseract
items.body:
Hello

I am doing binarization using separate algorithm and saving result as PNG and passing it to Tesseract. Since i have binarized it already i want Tesseract to stop applying its binarization (Otsu's) on my binarized image. What is the correct way to pass a binarized image to Tesseract so that it doesnt apply binarization on it?

Thanks
Uzair

items.title: 2.2.2 release

items.title: How do I install the tesserocr on windows?
Recent commit in Tesseract 4 breaks Tesserocr installation
items.body:
**This only applies to Tesseract 4**

This is an easy problem to solve but people might hit a wall if they aren't aware.

Commit [da03e4e](https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/commit/da03e4e9105b6262706d40ef2b4436eae4ebe19f#diff-4376fff11de6717e265623d40f1b0820) added the use of string in the unichar.h header file that is used during compilation by `tesserocr`. Unfortunately (and I'm not sure why, explanations are welcome) the standard library (std) is **not** included. This caused the compiler to throw an error

    In file included from tesserocr.cpp:484:0:
    /usr/local/include/tesseract/unichar.h:164:10: error: ‘string’ does not name a type
    static string UTF32ToUTF8(const std::vector<char32>& str32);
              ^

**Changing**  `static string UTF32ToUTF8(const std::vector<char32>& str32);` **to** `static std::string UTF32ToUTF8(const std::vector<char32>& str32);` **in** `/usr/local/include/tesseract/unichar.h:164` **fixes the problem for me.**

According to a comment that can be seen [here if you scroll a bit](https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract/commit/aee910a7bfcbe0366806b68dc7f20535764c06d4) Google seems to have a problem with **std::string** vs **string** so while I will open an issue on their repo, I feel it is unlikely that someone will fix it. Therefore I recommend using my "dirty hack".

Anyone with more knowledge than me is very welcome to clarify / propose something else.

items.title: Failed to recognize text  of boxes returned by GetComponentImages()
items.body: I want to recognize every word in the image above. When I run the code ``` from PIL import Image from tesserocr import PyTessBaseAPI, RIL image = Image.open('sample10.png') with PyTessBaseAPI() as api: api.SetImage(image) boxes = api.GetComponentImages(RIL.WORD, True) for i, (im, box, _, _) in enumerate(boxes): # im is a PIL image object # box is a dict with x, y, w and h keys api.SetRectangle(box['x'], box['y'], box['w'], 120) print api.GetUTF8Text() ``` It outputs nothing. But following code works. Why? ``` from PIL import Image from tesserocr import PyTessBaseAPI, RIL image = Image.open('sample10.png') with PyTessBaseAPI() as api: api.SetImage(image) print api.GetUTF8Text() ```

items.body:
The compilation on slightly older system (Ubuntu Precise used on Travis CI) fails:

```
  Supporting tesseract v3.04.01

  Configs from pkg-config: {'libraries': ['lept', 'tesseract'], 'cython_compile_time_env': {'TESSERACT_VERSION': 197633}, 'library_dirs': ['/home/travis/build/WeblateOrg/weblate/.tesseract/lib'], 'include_dirs': ['/home/travis/build/WeblateOrg/weblate/.tesseract/include']}

  running bdist_wheel

  running build

  running build_ext

  building 'tesserocr' extension

  creating build

  creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7

  gcc -pthread -fno-strict-aliasing -g -fstack-protector --param=ssp-buffer-size=4 -Wformat -Werror=format-security -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -fPIC -I/home/travis/build/WeblateOrg/weblate/.tesseract/include -I/opt/python/2.7.9/include/python2.7 -c tesserocr.cpp -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/tesserocr.o -std=c++11

  cc1plus: warning: command line option ‘-Wstrict-prototypes’ is valid for Ada/C/ObjC but not for C++ [enabled by default]

  cc1plus: error: unrecognized command line option ‘-std=c++11’

  error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
```

The problem seems to be in [setup.py line 130](https://github.com/sirfz/tesserocr/blob/9c7774e2435dbcde5101c3550c86b702550213cc/setup.py#L130) as that compares version which is comparing TESSERACT_VERSION which is `197633` at this point with `4.` while it should probably compare with `0x40000`.
